bug.title: Area disappears in Plot on Python
bug.body: try python code: ``` from beakerx import * plot9 = Plot() plot9.add(Line(y= [3, 6, 12, 24], displayName= "Median")) plot9.add(Area(y= [4, 8, 16, 32], base= [2, 4, 8, 16], color= Color(255, 0, 0, 50), displayName= "Q1 to Q3")) ``` when we move the mouse over name of Area , the Area in Plot will disappear ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17744188/67761836-24ea2680-fa55-11e9-9db4-f1e30af759b6.png) Look at right behavior on groovy ``` def p = new Plot() p << new Line(y: [3, 6, 12, 24], displayName: "Median") p << new Area(y: [4, 8, 16, 32], base: [2, 4, 8, 16], color: new Color(255, 0, 0, 50), displayName: "Q1 to Q3") ``` When we move the mouse over name of Area it will changes to more highlight color ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17744188/67761667-ccb32480-fa54-11e9-8ff5-450b54b060cc.png)

bug.title: CategoryPlot fill property (Groovy vs Python)
bug.body: `fill = false ` works on Groovy and doesn't work on python Groovy: ``` def bars = new CategoryBars(value: [[1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6]], fill: false) new CategoryPlot() << bars ``` ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17744188/57523946-0ff6cb00-732f-11e9-848e-cb00c3f13b98.png) Python: ``` bars = CategoryBars(value = [[1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6]], fill = False) CategoryPlot().add(bars) ``` ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17744188/57524036-53e9d000-732f-11e9-8a3c-f836d9848132.png)

bug.title: Combined Plot bug on JavaScript
bug.body: Try this code: ``` %%javascript var x = [1, 4, 6, 8, 10] var y = [3, 6, 4, 5, 9] var p1 = new beakerx.Plot({title: 'Plot1'}) p1.add(new beakerx.Line({displayName: "Line1", x: x, y: y, width: 3})) var p2 = new beakerx.Plot({title: 'Plot2'}) p2.add(new beakerx.Line({displayName: "Line2", x: x, y: x, width: 3})) var cp = new beakerx.CombinedPlot({title: "Combined Plot"}) cp.add(p1); cp.add(p2); cp.display(this); ``` We get 4 plots instead of two. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17744188/55785996-112ca200-5abc-11e9-8c6f-16ca2d7549e2.png)

bug.title: No connection to kernel
bug.body: To reproduce this error: build new environment, install beakerx by our instruction, run jupyter notebook, open any notebook. The result no any kernels will works. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17744188/54426120-1cdcb100-4728-11e9-9fb2-0277425b3d07.png) browser console: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17744188/54426311-88268300-4728-11e9-8b83-4261abad410d.png) warning on console: ``` c:\aconda3\envs\test_env\lib\site-packages\notebook\base\zmqhandlers.py:284: Run timeWarning: coroutine 'WebSocketHandler.get' was never awaited super(AuthenticatedZMQStreamHandler, self).get(*args, **kwargs) RuntimeWarning: Enable tracemalloc to get the object allocation traceback ```

bug.title: Error: Circular reference detected (Python table)
bug.body: try http://localhost:8888/notebooks/test/ipynb/python/TableAPIPythonTest.ipynb notebook and cell with code: ``` import pandas as pd from beakerx import * from beakerx.object import beakerx #Display mode: TableDisplay Widget beakerx.pandas_display_table() pd.DataFrame(data=np.zeros((5,5)), index=pd.Int64Index([0, 1, 2, 3, 4], dtype='int64')) ``` ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17744188/51612931-7a782c80-1f33-11e9-89f6-7a7c0adf65cb.png)

bug.title: AttributeError for 'TreeMapNode'
bug.body: try this code on python: ``` from beakerx import * menuNode = TreeMapNode("0") for i in range(1, 600): nodeX = TreeMapNode("X" + str(i)) nodeX.add(TreeMapNode("a" + str(i), i, DefaultValue(i))) nodeX.add(TreeMapNode("b" + str(i), i, DefaultValue(i))) menuNode.add(nodeX) x = TreeMap( root= menuNode, showLegend= True, title= "many nodes TreeChart" ) x ``` we will get the error: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17744188/50142942-35f9d100-02a3-11e9-8de5-0a1bd76179ca.png)

bug.title: java.lang.IllegalStateException on TreeMap
bug.body: try this code on groovy: ``` Random random = new Random(); rootNode = new TreeMapNode("0"); 500.times{ n = random.nextInt(10); nodeX = new TreeMapNode("X" + n) nodeX.add(new TreeMapNode("a" + n, n, new DefaultValue(n))) nodeX.add(new TreeMapNode("b" + n, n, new DefaultValue(n))) rootNode.add(nodeX) } def x = new TreeMap( root: rootNode, showLegend: true, title: "many nodes TreeChart" ); x ``` the using 1501 nodes throws the java.lang.IllegalStateException ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17744188/49733118-c4fa5e00-fc91-11e8-8069-e842c2cd975b.png) for 1201 nodes it works right and displays expected message ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17744188/49733210-f96e1a00-fc91-11e8-86b1-02052107461f.png)

bug.title: ANTLR version conflict between Spark 2.3 and base
bug.body: Spark started using ANTLR 4.7 as of Spark 2.3.0, where previously it used 4.5. BeakerX base is using version 4.5. Some operations (any that involve parsing SQL, I imagine) trigger a problem. The ANTLR runtime complains ``` ANTLR Tool version 4.7 used for code generation does not match the current runtime version 4.5ANTLR Runtime version 4.7 used for parser compilation does not match the current runtime version 4.5 java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException: java.io.InvalidClassException: org.antlr.v4.runtime.atn.ATN; Could not deserialize ATN with UUID 59627784-3be5-417a-b9eb-8131a7286089 (expected aadb8d7e-aeef-4415-ad2b-8204d6cf042e or a legacy UUID). at org.antlr.v4.runtime.atn.ATNDeserializer.deserialize(ATNDeserializer.java:154) at org.apache.spark.sql.catalyst.parser.SqlBaseLexer.<clinit>(SqlBaseLexer.java:1153) at org.apache.spark.sql.catalyst.parser.AbstractSqlParser.parse(ParseDriver.scala:84) at org.apache.spark.sql.catalyst.parser.AbstractSqlParser.parseDataType(ParseDriver.scala:39) at org.apache.spark.sql.Column.cast(Column.scala:1017) ... 52 elided Caused by: java.io.InvalidClassException: org.antlr.v4.runtime.atn.ATN; Could not deserialize ATN with UUID 59627784-3be5-417a-b9eb-8131a7286089 (expected aadb8d7e-aeef-4415-ad2b-8204d6cf042e or a legacy UUID). ... 57 more ``` I don't know whether moving the base version to 4.7 would cause problems for Spark <2.3. It looks to me like ANTLR is only being used by the Groovy and Java kernels, and is not actually used by base. So taking the dependency out of base might be a workaround. Oh, sample problem generator: ``` spark.sql("") ``` (after loading and starting spark 2.3.1)

bug.body: Conversation of map to TableDisplay corrupts map itself instead of creating a copy: ```Groovy def b = ["a" : 2, "b" : 3, "c" : 4] println(b) println(b.a) ``` [a:2, b:3, c:4] 2 ```Groovy println(b) println(b.a) ``` [type:TableDisplay, columnNames:[Key, Value], values:[[a, 2], [b, 3], [c, 4]], subtype:Dictionary] null

bug.title: spark status minimum width
bug.body: like the spark progress task counters, the spark status indicators should have a minimum width to prevent them from shifting horizontally as the numbers change. the green one is fine as it is. the red and blue ones should be hold 3 digits without changing width. the gray one should hold 3 digits plus the space and unit indicator without changing width too.

You can make this conversion explicit by writing `Math _` or `Math(_)` instead of `Math`. val x = Math.random() ``` @jpallas

bug.title: column drag-n-drop wrong destination with index
bug.body: to reproduce: 1) in doc/python/TableAPI.ipynb run this: ``` df = pd.read_csv('../resources/data/interest-rates.csv') df.set_index(['m3']) ``` 2) then click and start a drag a column like "y1". if you only move the mouse a few pixels for the drag to start, a blue line appears to the right of the "y1" column, indicating the target of the drop, which should not change the table because we are dropping it at its current location. 3) release the mouse to drop the column. result: the y1 column moves to the left of "y30". expected result: column stays in its original location.

bug.title: Spark Dataset preview appears in wrong location
bug.body: I have a notebook with four cells: 1. `%%classpath add mvn` `org.apache.spark spark-sql_2.11 2.3.1` 2. `%%spark -c` 3. `val ds1 = spark.createDataset(Seq(("a", "this", 7), ("b", "this", 5), ("b", "that", 11)))` 4. `val ds2 = spark.range(1, 10)` After running all four cells, my notebook looks like this: ![screen shot 2018-06-20 at 2 50 28 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4623910/41686566-63b3a140-7499-11e8-9e97-a4630b8dbe9b.png) If I click on the "Preview 10 Rows" button in cell 3, I get this: ![screen shot 2018-06-20 at 2 52 42 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4623910/41686648-aeeb2d0e-7499-11e8-9c9f-0435b1df9262.png) The preview of ds1 from cell 3 appears in the output area for cell 4, below the preview button and schema info for ds2. If I click on ds2's preview button at this point, the Spark status indicator and data preview will appear below the preview of ds1 (but all still in the cell 4 output area).

bug.title: Filtering with $ not working for Tables with column names with multiple spaces
bug.body: Hello beakerX folks, you made my life so much easier, so thank you for the great work (especially with these tables!). Found an issue (I think) that is able to be reproduced inside of the TableAPI.ipynb example notebook environment from inside Binder. (if more info is needed, please reach out). I created this simple table from a defined pandas dataframe to demonstrate and ran it in a new cell in the notebook: ``` table=TableDisplay(pd.DataFrame(data=[[4.0,'Hello',1.0], [2.9,'World',3.2]], columns=['col 1try','col2','col3'])) table ``` It looks like this after I turn on the "Filter by Expression" ![filteredpresuccess](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23373651/41467844-d7b4cf7c-709f-11e8-853c-948b4ddddaf3.PNG) I then attempt to filter the column 'col 1try' like this (even without using 3.0): ![filteredsuccess](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23373651/41467879-f0d45c8e-709f-11e8-8bd6-bbcfcb322956.PNG) Which works as I would think. Wonderful. Now when I change the name of the column from 'col 1try' to 'col 1 try' (whitespace between 1 and try) like this: ``` table=TableDisplay(pd.DataFrame(data=[[4.0,'Hello',1.0], [2.9,'World',3.2]], columns=['col 1 try','col2','col3'])) table ``` I get this after I turn on the "Filter by Expression": ![filteredprefailure](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23373651/41468098-ada189d6-70a0-11e8-9962-f626fea9b387.PNG) I then attempt to filter the column 'col 1 try' like this: ![filteredfailure](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23373651/41468124-c509d0ce-70a0-11e8-8a87-2198f063ae74.PNG) And get no filtering action. I've tried 3.0 and nothing still. From what I can tell it appears to be column names with non-consecutive whitespaces. I tried it with success for multiple whitespaces and it behaved as in the first scenario. I'm am unsure whether this is actually a bug or just a nuance of the table text parsing engine, or whether I should be using different syntax for the logic, so feedback would be appreciated. Thanks everyone!

bug.title: handle failure in spark getOrCreate
bug.body: enter a bad master url, like `spark://1.2.3.4:7077` after a timeout of a minute, i get a stack trace and then kernel dies. ``` 2018-06-02 15:48:10:746 -0400 [Thread-0] ERROR SparkContext - Error initializing SparkContext. java.lang.NullPointerException at org.apache.spark.SparkContext.<init>(SparkContext.scala:567) at org.apache.spark.SparkContext$.getOrCreate(SparkContext.scala:2516) at org.apache.spark.sql.SparkSession$Builder$$anonfun$6.apply(SparkSession.scala:918) at org.apache.spark.sql.SparkSession$Builder$$anonfun$6.apply(SparkSession.scala:910) at scala.Option.getOrElse(Option.scala:121) at org.apache.spark.sql.SparkSession$Builder.getOrCreate(SparkSession.scala:910) at com.twosigma.beakerx.widget.SparkEngineImpl.getOrCreate(SparkEngineImpl.java:86) at com.twosigma.beakerx.widget.SparkEngineImpl.configure(SparkEngineImpl.java:74) at com.twosigma.beakerx.widget.SparkUI.initSparkContext(SparkUI.java:165) at com.twosigma.beakerx.widget.SparkUI.lambda$createConnectButton$0(SparkUI.java:158) at com.twosigma.beakerx.widget.Button.onClick(Button.java:93) at com.twosigma.beakerx.widget.CompiledCodeRunner.runCommEvent(CompiledCodeRunner.java:54) at com.twosigma.beakerx.widget.Widget.lambda$handleCommEventSync$0(Widget.java:167) at com.twosigma.beakerx.handler.KernelHandlerWrapper.wrapBusyIdle(KernelHandlerWrapper.java:25) at com.twosigma.beakerx.widget.Widget.handleCommEventSync(Widget.java:167) at com.twosigma.beakerx.widget.Button.handleOnClick(Button.java:88) at com.twosigma.beakerx.kernel.comm.Comm.handleMsg(Comm.java:297) at com.twosigma.beakerx.kernel.handler.CommMsgHandler.handleMsg(CommMsgHandler.java:53) at com.twosigma.beakerx.kernel.handler.CommMsgHandler.lambda$handle$0(CommMsgHandler.java:43) at com.twosigma.beakerx.handler.KernelHandlerWrapper.wrapBusyIdle(KernelHandlerWrapper.java:25) at com.twosigma.beakerx.kernel.handler.CommMsgHandler.handle(CommMsgHandler.java:42) at com.twosigma.beakerx.kernel.handler.CommMsgHandler.handle(CommMsgHandler.java:33) at com.twosigma.beakerx.socket.KernelSocketsZMQ.handleShell(KernelSocketsZMQ.java:190) at com.twosigma.beakerx.socket.KernelSocketsZMQ.run(KernelSocketsZMQ.java:165) ``` * there should be a spinner until it starts or errs. * if it errs, it should return to the form (not go to connected/status). * the form then shows the error in red, the the right of the "start" button. * if spark API reports an error string or code, show it in red too. i found some other errors do show in red correctly, so this issue is really about handling this specific error. adding the spinner is not high priority, that can go in a 2nd PR.

bug.title: rename connect to start
bug.body: in doc/scala/SparkUI.ipynb > You can also provide a --connect (or -c) option to automatically connect with the cluster. should read > You can also provide a --start (or -s) option to automatically start a session with the cluster or a local instance.

bug.title: Save beakerx.json to paths specified in JUPTYER_CONFIG_DIR
bug.body: The `%%spark` magic is currently [hardwired](https://github.com/twosigma/beakerx/blob/0.18.2/kernel/sparkex/src/main/java/com/twosigma/beakerx/scala/magic/command/SparkMagicCommand.java#L62) to store its configuration at `Paths.get(System.getProperty("user.home") + File.separator + ".jupyter" + File.separator + "beakerx.json"))));` It should instead honor paths (if) specified in the `JUPYTER_CONFIG_DIR` environment variable e.g., I have `JUPYTER_CONFIG_DIR` set to `/mnt/mesos/sandbox/.jupyter` which yields the following acceptable config locations with `jupyter --paths`: ``` $ jupyter --paths config: /mnt/mesos/sandbox/.jupyter /opt/conda/etc/jupyter /usr/local/etc/jupyter /etc/jupyter data: /mnt/mesos/sandbox/.local/share/jupyter /opt/conda/share/jupyter /usr/local/share/jupyter /usr/share/jupyter runtime: /mnt/mesos/sandbox/.local/share/jupyter/runtime ``` Instead, the Spark Magic fails to initialize when I run the notebook as the non-privileged user `nobody` because it attempts to store `beakerx.json` under `/nonexistent/.jupyter`, which as the name implies, is non-existent :) ``` $ grep nobody /etc/passwd nobody:x:65534:65534:nobody:/nonexistent:/usr/sbin/nologin ```

bug.body: In general a user could import 'plot' from matplotlib by calling: `from matplotlib.pyplot import plot` But if user have another cell importing everything from beakerx: `from beakerx import *` Then all plotting in matplot lib would fail with exception: 'TypeError: module object is not callable' Because beakerx.plot override the matplotlib plot.

bug.title: spark progress for concurrent jobs
bug.body: ``` import scala.concurrent._ import scala.concurrent.ExecutionContext.Implicits.global val NUM_SAMPLES = 1000000 var count = 0 Future({ count += spark.sparkContext.parallelize(1 to NUM_SAMPLES).map{i => Thread.sleep(2) val x = Math.random() val y = Math.random() if (x*x + y*y < 1) 1 else 0 }.reduce(_ + _)}) Future({ count += spark.sparkContext.parallelize(1 to NUM_SAMPLES).map{i => Thread.sleep(2) val x = Math.random() val y = Math.random() if (x*x + y*y < 1) 1 else 0 }.reduce(_ + _)}) OutputCell.HIDDEN ``` should get 2 progress bars at the same time

bug.title: Checkbox not working correctly
bug.body: The checkboxes seem to be sharing an underlying object. See the image for a proper explanation. ![screenshot from 2018-05-03 08-46-51](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7573669/39587548-a10d33be-4eae-11e8-8d39-d37349d2d7d8.png) Specifics: I'm just trying out beakerx now with python 3.6 from anaconda. I installed via: conda install -c conda-forge beakerx ipywidgets I grabbed the current examples: git clone https://github.com/twosigma/beakerx.git I set a cell in my notebook to this: g = EasyForm("Field Types") g.addCheckBoxes("Check Boxes 1", ["a", "b", "c", "d"], orientation=EasyForm.HORIZONTAL) g.addCheckBoxes("Check Boxes 2", ["a", "b", "c", "d"], orientation=EasyForm.HORIZONTAL) g.addCheckBoxes("Check Boxes 3", ["a", "b", "c", "e"], orientation=EasyForm.HORIZONTAL) g.addButton("Go!", tag="run2") I checked: a a,b b I clicked Go and ran the next cell: result = dict() for child in g: result[child] = g[child] result Which output: {'Check Boxes 1': ['b', 'a', 'a', 'b', 'b'], 'Check Boxes 2': ['b', 'a', 'a', 'b', 'b'], 'Check Boxes 3': ['b', 'a', 'a', 'b', 'b']} after checking 'e' in the 3rd row, it becomes this: {'Check Boxes 1': ['b', 'a', 'a', 'b', 'b', 'e'], 'Check Boxes 2': ['b', 'a', 'a', 'b', 'b', 'e'], 'Check Boxes 3': ['b', 'a', 'a', 'b', 'b', 'e']}

bug.title: column type tooltips stay up too long

bug.body: this groovy table: ``` d=1e8 v=[[t:d,value:null], [t:2*d, value:Double.NaN],[t:3*d, value:5.5]] ``` null should display as blank but instead is showing as "null".

bug.title: enum not supported with Groovy
bug.body: I'm running BeakerX 0.15.2. This was also an issue with 0.14.0. I have an empty Groovy notebook. I add a single code cell ``` enum X { A, B, C } ``` and execute the notebook. BeakerX response with ``` java.lang.InstantiationException: X at com.twosigma.beakerx.groovy.evaluator.GroovyCodeRunner.call(GroovyCodeRunner.java:60) at com.twosigma.beakerx.groovy.evaluator.GroovyCodeRunner.call(GroovyCodeRunner.java:36) Caused by: java.lang.NoSuchMethodException: X.<init>() at java.lang.Class.getConstructor0(Class.java:3082) at java.lang.Class.newInstance(Class.java:412) at com.twosigma.beakerx.groovy.evaluator.GroovyCodeRunner.call(GroovyCodeRunner.java:60) at com.twosigma.beakerx.groovy.evaluator.GroovyCodeRunner.call(GroovyCodeRunner.java:36) at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.run(FutureTask.java:266) at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1142) at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:617) at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745) ``` It is possible this is related to https://github.com/twosigma/beakerx/issues/7185 but the reporter of that issue didn't report the specific error.

bug.title: make table tests use fuzzy matching
bug.body: since the new tables use canvas, e2e tests need to compare images with fuzzy matching. even when we use the same OS (ubuntu) and the same version of chrome (63) there are some small differences: https://nbviewer.jupyter.org/gist/scottdraves/08d731e32101d1eb0ab3b191771665f7 2.5% of the pixels are off by one. use https://www.npmjs.com/package/resemblejs to allow errors like this. i am OK with requiring ubuntu for e2e tests since it is easy to run with virtualbox. comparing linux and mac: https://nbviewer.jupyter.org/gist/scottdraves/4aa1c94b6f0bf49768efb7f621d7bb9c we might be able to tune the fuzziness to accept these kinds of diffs, or find some configs to reduce the diffs. will leave this for future work.

bug.title: frozen index breaks table widget
bug.body: Run the following Python3 code: ``` from beakerx import * z = TableDisplay([]) z.model = {'alignmentForColumn': {}, 'alignmentForType': {}, 'cellHighlighters': [], 'columnNames': ['time'], 'columnOrder': [], 'columnsFrozen': {"time":True}, 'columnsFrozenRight': {}, 'columnsVisible': {}, 'contextMenuItems': [], 'contextMenuTags': {}, 'fontColor': [], 'hasDoubleClickAction': False, 'hasIndex': 'true', 'headersVertical': False, 'rendererForColumn': {}, 'rendererForType': {}, 'stringFormatForColumn': {}, 'stringFormatForType': {}, 'subtype': 'Dictionary', 'tooManyRows': False, 'tooltips': [], 'type': 'TableDisplay', 'timeZone': 'UTC', 'types': ['datetime'], 'values': [['1420174800.0']]} z ``` get the following JS stack trace: ``` selectors.ts:128 Uncaught (in promise) TypeError: Cannot read property 'index' of undefined at selectors.ts:128 at index.js:76 at index.js:36 at index.js:90 at index.js:36 at ColumnPosition.getColumnByPosition (ColumnPosition.ts:72) at DataGridResize.setInitialSectionWidth (DataGridResize.ts:89) at DataGridResize.setInitialSectionWidths (DataGridResize.ts:84) at DataGridResize.setInitialSize (DataGridResize.ts:49) at BeakerxDataGrid.init (BeakerxDataGrid.ts:121) ``` the issue seems to be ` 'columnsFrozen': {"time":True},` which is redundant because it's the index, but should not break it. The old tables handle it.

bug.title: more key cmds
bug.body: 1. keyboard navigation (arrow keys or page up/down) with shift-key down should select region from clicked cell to current cell. 2. enter key should be like clicking the current cell.

bug.title: mouse indicator for drag column width is janky
bug.body: when the mouse hovers over the edge of a column header, it should turn to the horizontal resize arrows. it seems the zone is too small, i have to hunt for it and it rarely appears. this is broken. the zone that works for clicking is fortunately bigger and works but is a bit too small, please increase a bit. the two should match.

bug.title: menu moves too far
bug.body: sometimes the menu appears above the mouse instead of below: but this happens when the menu is too tall to fit between the bottom of the window and the mouse location. but now the most accessible items are the least useful, and the common commands are far away. can the menu be only moved as far as it needs to be to stay on-screen? this would be less of a problem if the menu were shorter as well. could it be two-column? use more horizontal space.

bug.title: new tables should be opt-out
bug.body: currently they are opt-in. users should get new tables by default.

bug.title: position and resolution of sort indicator
bug.body: the triangle that appears when you sort a column is blurry, please use svg or a higher resolution png. also, move it left to be in the same position as the hamburger menu.

bug.title: column menu highlight should be smaller
bug.body: ![screen shot 2018-03-22 at 9 40 28 am 2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/963093/37774013-7a77cf9e-2db5-11e8-8eea-345dd8ea4240.png) the blue highlight is too wide. the hamburger menu should be in the center of it. the hamburger menu is positioned correctly, do not move it, just move the right edge back to narrow it. it should be a rectangle not a square.

bug.title: tables should support drag-and-drop to re-order columns
tables should take focus on menu use
bug.body: if you click on a table body then it gets the focus for scroll and key events. this should also be true if you click on a table menu. when you click to open the table or column menu, the green focus should appear right away.

bug.title: legend missing from plot save-as
bug.body: render a plot with a legend, like ``` new Plot() << new Line(displayName: "A", y: [1, 2]) << new Line(displayName: "B", y: [1.5, 3]) ``` then right-click and "save as PNG". the problem is the legend is missing in the PNG. it should draw it too. it should automatically set omitCheckboxes: true for the exported legend.

bug.title: should use splitext
bug.body: https://github.com/twosigma/beakerx/blob/master/beakerx/beakerx/bkr2ipynb.py#L87 partition isn't right, for example running "beakerx bkr2ipynb ./foo.bkr" will fail. should use os.path.splitext instead.

bug.title: Support for Python 3.4 broken
bug.body: Hello, in `beakerx/install.py`, line 128, the exist_ok keyword parameter is used. This parameter was introduced in Python 3.5, and so older version of Python 3 will fail.

bug.title: jvm process leak from groovy magic
bug.body: when then python kernel is closed, it should close the groovy kernel too. right now, the process is leaking. to reproduce: 1) killall java; ps x | grep java 2) open doc/python/GroovyMagic.ipynb and run all cells 3) File -> Close and Halt 4) ps x | grep java expected: no java process result: java process be sure to check result of control-C on the jupyter cmd line as well.

bug.title: groovy magic starts jvm for every python shell
bug.body: the groovy kernel should be started lazily when %%groovy is first used, not when the magic is initialized.

bug.title: saving notebooks broken for doc folder
bug.body: to reproduce: open starthere.ipynb, click on first "Groovy" notebook, run teh 1st cell, then hit cmd-S (or control-S on windows or linux). result: nothing happens expected result: notebook is saved

bug.title: pandas using widget without import
bug.body: ``` import pandas as pd pd.DataFrame() ``` is giving me this stack trace: ``` --------------------------------------------------------------------------- UnboundLocalError Traceback (most recent call last) ~/anaconda/envs/beakerx/lib/python3.6/site-packages/IPython/core/formatters.py in __call__(self, obj) 916 method = get_real_method(obj, self.print_method) 917 if method is not None: --> 918 method() 919 return True 920 ~/src/beakerx/beakerx/beakerx/runtime.py in f() 421 def __get__(self, model_instance, model_class): 422 def f(): --> 423 display_html(TableDisplay(model_instance)) 424 return f 425 ~/src/beakerx/beakerx/beakerx/tabledisplay/tabledisplay.py in __init__(self, *args, **kwargs) 191 def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): 192 super(TableDisplay, self).__init__(**kwargs) --> 193 self.chart = Table(*args, **kwargs) 194 self.model = self.chart.transform() 195 self.on_msg(self.handle_msg) ~/src/beakerx/beakerx/beakerx/tabledisplay/tabledisplay.py in __init__(self, *args, **kwargs) 33 self.hasIndex = None 34 if isinstance(args[0], DataFrame): ---> 35 self.convert_from_pandas(args, types_map) 36 elif isinstance(args[0], dict): 37 self.convert_from_dict(args) ~/src/beakerx/beakerx/beakerx/tabledisplay/tabledisplay.py in convert_from_pandas(self, args, types_map) 123 else: 124 self.columnNames[:0] = [args[0].index.name] --> 125 self.types[:0] = [self.convert_type("", args[0][column].get_values()[0])] 126 127 @staticmethod UnboundLocalError: local variable 'column' referenced before assignment ``` there are 2 problems. 1) displaying pandas dataframes with the widget should only be enabled if you "import beakerx" or "from beakerx import *". it seems to be enabled by default, incorrectly. 2) an empty dataframe is crashing our displayer.

bug.title: sections of options should use tabs
bug.body: in the BeakerX panel of the tree view, the UI Options and JVM Options sections should be in a tabbed container.

bug.title: Failed import produces no error message
bug.body: The code below produces no error message even though `com.github.lwhite1.tablesaw.api.QueryHelper.column` is not valid (it should be `tech.tablesaw.api.QueryHelper.column`) ``` %%classpath add mvn tech.tablesaw tablesaw-core 0.11.4 tech.tablesaw tablesaw-beakerx 0.11.4 ``` ``` %import tech.tablesaw.api.* %import tech.tablesaw.columns.* %import tech.tablesaw.io.csv.* %import static com.github.lwhite1.tablesaw.api.QueryHelper.column // display Tablesaw tables with BeakerX table display widget tech.tablesaw.beakerx.TablesawDisplayer.register() ```

bug.title: Beakerx TableDisplay breaks bqplot GridHeatMap
bug.body: Jupyter Notebook v5.3 OS: Windows 10 Beakerx v0.12.1 BQPlot v0.10.2 -------------------------------------- Hi, I really like the BeakerX table. Very nice job. However, I'm having issues with TableDisplay when using BQplot heatmaps. After I create a TableDisplay widget, the BQplot heatmap or gridheatmap goes blank. Here is an example: ```python from __future__ import print_function import numpy as np from bqplot import * np.random.seed(0) data = np.random.randn(10, 10) col_sc = ColorScale() grid_map = GridHeatMap(color=data, scales={'color': col_sc}) fig = Figure(marks=[grid_map], padding_y=0.0) fig ``` ```python import beakerx as bx import pandas as pd bx.TableDisplay(pd.DataFrame(index = [0],columns= ['blank'])) ``` ```python fig ```

bug.title: Make an uninstall process to restore previous environment
bug.body: I remember seeing that beakerx installed some things in jupyter's folder. After doing some tests, I would like to uninstall it, but I didn't find any references to how to delete those files. I realized that `pip uninstall beakerx` is not enough, because it left some config files behind, making old `jupyter notebook` broken. After removing both `.jupyter` and `.ipython` config folders, I managed to get a cleaner error output. ``` $ jupyter notebook [W 18:50:10.914 NotebookApp] Error loading server extension beakerx Traceback (most recent call last): File "python_path/lib/python3.6/site-packages/notebook/notebookapp.py", line 1343, in init_server_extensions mod = importlib.import_module(modulename) File "python_path/lib/python3.6/importlib/__init__.py", line 126, in import_module return _bootstrap._gcd_import(name[level:], package, level) File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 978, in _gcd_import File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 961, in _find_and_load File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 948, in _find_and_load_unlocked ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'beakerx' [I 18:50:10.937 NotebookApp] [jupyter_nbextensions_configurator] enabled 0.2.8 [I 18:50:10.997 NotebookApp] Serving notebooks from local directory: /home/paulo/Documents/work/scorer-svc [I 18:50:10.997 NotebookApp] 0 active kernels [I 18:50:10.997 NotebookApp] The Jupyter Notebook is running at: [I 18:50:10.997 NotebookApp] http://localhost:8888/?token=4261729b3fb906e6e2d70259a809e4429646eec24e031792 [I 18:50:10.997 NotebookApp] Use Control-C to stop this server and shut down all kernels (twice to skip confirmation). [C 18:50:10.999 NotebookApp] Copy/paste this URL into your browser when you connect for the first time, to login with a token: http://localhost:8888/?token=4261729b3fb906e6e2d70259a809e4429646eec24e031792 [I 18:50:12.073 NotebookApp] Accepting one-time-token-authenticated connection from 127.0.0.1 [14437:14477:0115/185012.104051:ERROR:browser_gpu_channel_host_factory.cc(107)] Failed to launch GPU process. Created new window in existing browser session. [W 18:50:13.006 NotebookApp] 404 GET /nbextensions/beakerx/tree.js (127.0.0.1) 10.89ms referer=http://localhost:8888/tree ``` Running `jupyter notebook --debug`, I could manage to backtrack the following config files: * `python_env_path/etc/{jupyter,ipython}` * `python_env_path/share/jupyter/kernels/{groovy,clojure,sql,scala,java,kotlin}` * `python_env_path/share/jupyter/nbextensions/beakerx` As I had no previous configuration in them, I deleted all of them and then I got my Jupyter again.

bug.title: Error: Script error for "beakerx" after saving the widgets state and reloading page
What's going on with set[yY]AutoRange?
bug.body: While working on the Scala getters and setters, I stumbled across a peculiar situation. `setYAutoRange` is defined on `XYChart`, while `setyAutoRange` is defined in both `AbstractChart` and `XYChart`. The definition in `AbstractChart` looks reasonable: ```java public AbstractChart setyAutoRange(boolean yAutoRange) { this.yAxis.setAutoRange(yAutoRange); sendModelUpdate(ChartToJson.serializeAutoRange(this.yAxis.getAutoRange())); return this; } ``` The definition of `setyAutoRange` in `XYChart` just delegates to `setYAutoRange`: ```java public XYChart setyAutoRange(boolean yAutoRange) { return this.setYAutoRange(yAutoRange); } ``` The definition of `setYAutoRange` in `XYChart` looks insane: ```java public XYChart setYAutoRange(boolean yAutoRange) { setXAutoRange(yAutoRange); return this; } ``` What is going on here? The Java bean-style property naming conventions invite confusion about property names that start with a one-letter "word", so the fact that both variants exist isn't surprising. Groovy follows the [formal rules](http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/documentation/spec-136004.html) implemented by [`Introspector`](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/beans/Introspector.html#decapitalize-java.lang.String-), so it thinks `[gs]etYAutoRange` methods define a property named `YAutoRange` and not one named `yAutoRange`. Users, of course, expect the name `yAutoRange` because it certainly doesn't occur to them that the "YA" in "YAutoRange" looks like the start of an acronym. Since `XYChart` extends `AbstractChart`, my best guess is that the inconsistency in naming was noticed and something went horribly wrong in an attempt to fix it. It seems like the fix should have been applied in `AbstractChart` but was instead applied in `XYChart` and just got messed up.

bug.title: Right-click menu interferes with box zoom functionality
bug.body: http://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/twosigma/beakerx/blob/master/doc/groovy/Charting.ipynb#Navigation says: >Box Zoom You can zoom to a selected rectangle region. Right click the mouse and drag out the box youd like to zoom into. You do NOT necessarily need to drag the box from the left-top to the bottom-right. Any direction will do The issue I'm having is that when you right click it pops up a menu with the options: * Save as SVG * Save as PNG * Save as PNG as high DPI...

bug.title: mvn commands overwrite each other?
bug.body: I'm alternately getting tablesaw 0.9 (pulled in transitively via `quandl-tablesaw`) and 0.11 on my classpath. At first I thought it might be related to the ordering. E.g. this: ``` %classpath add mvn tech.tablesaw tablesaw-core 0.11.4 %classpath add mvn tech.tablesaw tablesaw-beakerx 0.11.4 %classpath add mvn com.jimmoores quandl-tablesaw 2.0.0 ``` Vs this: ``` %classpath add mvn com.jimmoores quandl-tablesaw 2.0.0 %classpath add mvn tech.tablesaw tablesaw-core 0.11.4 %classpath add mvn tech.tablesaw tablesaw-beakerx 0.11.4 ``` Now I'm thinking it's just random. The way I would expect this to work is that each `%classpath add` adds to the list of Maven dependencies and then they all get resolved together.

bug.title: beakerx.json format change: heap size should be float
bug.body: followup to https://github.com/twosigma/beakerx/issues/6511 1) change the `heap_GB` field to use a float not a string. keep the file format version at 2. if the user has not entered any value at all, instead of "" use null. 2) harden the server code that reads and interprets this file to any error. eg say the user edits the file by hand and leaves a syntax error in the json, then starts beakerx, then all of our kernels fail to load and a bunch of stack traces like this are dumped: ``` [E 11:12:07.493 NotebookApp] Failed to load kernel spec: 'sql' Traceback (most recent call last): File "/Users/spot/anaconda/envs/beakerx/lib/python3.6/site-packages/notebook/services/kernelspecs/handlers.py", line 57, in get d = kernelspec_model(self, kernel_name) File "/Users/spot/anaconda/envs/beakerx/lib/python3.6/site-packages/notebook/services/kernelspecs/handlers.py", line 22, in kernelspec_model spec = ksm.get_kernel_spec(name) File "/Users/spot/anaconda/envs/beakerx/lib/python3.6/site-packages/jupyter_client/kernelspec.py", line 205, in get_kernel_spec return self._get_kernel_spec_by_name(kernel_name, resource_dir) File "/Users/spot/anaconda/envs/beakerx/lib/python3.6/site-packages/jupyter_client/kernelspec.py", line 192, in _get_kernel_spec_by_name return self.kernel_spec_class.from_resource_dir(resource_dir) File "/Users/spot/anaconda/envs/beakerx/lib/python3.6/site-packages/jupyter_client/kernelspec.py", line 41, in from_resource_dir return cls(resource_dir=resource_dir, **kernel_dict) File "/Users/spot/src/beakerx/beakerx/beakerx/kernel_spec.py", line 23, in __init__ args = EnvironmentSettings.read_beakerx_env_settings() File "/Users/spot/src/beakerx/beakerx/beakerx/environment.py", line 81, in read_beakerx_env_settings settings = json.loads(EnvironmentSettings.read_setting_from_file()) File "/Users/spot/src/beakerx/beakerx/beakerx/environment.py", line 52, in read_setting_from_file beakerx_settings = json.loads(content) File "/Users/spot/anaconda/envs/beakerx/lib/python3.6/json/__init__.py", line 354, in loads return _default_decoder.decode(s) File "/Users/spot/anaconda/envs/beakerx/lib/python3.6/json/decoder.py", line 339, in decode obj, end = self.raw_decode(s, idx=_w(s, 0).end()) File "/Users/spot/anaconda/envs/beakerx/lib/python3.6/json/decoder.py", line 355, in raw_decode obj, end = self.scan_once(s, idx) json.decoder.JSONDecodeError: Expecting ',' delimiter: line 15 column 1 (char 286) ``` instead, the error should be reported with line and column, but then config the file should just be ignored and the kernel should still be loaded.

bug.title: Scala input/output problem after classpath add
bug.body: While #6508 fixed the problem with the Scala interpreter going bonkers, there seems to be something odd happening with the first line of input after a class path change. ``` In [1]: println("line 1"); "first input" line 1 Out[1]: first input In [2]: %classpath add mvn org.scalacheck scalacheck_2.11 1.13.5 Added jars: [test-interface-1.0.jar, scala-library-2.11.8.jar, scalacheck_2.11-1.13.5.jar] In [3]: println("line 3"); "third input" Out[3]: first input In [4]: println("line 4"); "fourth input" line 4 Out[4]: fourth input ``` It looks like the input may not be processed, and a previous result is being returned. Or something. It's confusing. Only seems to show up if the `%classpath` is not the first input.

bug.title: Incorrect type inference results in date parsing error ("Unknown string format")
bug.body: | Version | |-----------| | 0.9.1 | I've happened across a bug where BeakerX is trying to automatically parse a string field that looks "date-like" but that isn't actually a date (i.e. is an `[object]` type in the dataframe rather than a `datetime64[ns]` type). I came across this while trying to display a dataset that contains references to particular runways (string types containing integers, usually in the range 0-36). It parses the first few rows of my dataset happily enough (as these rows coincidentally are < 31 and therefore - I guess - get parsed as days). However, if BeakerX encounters a string that doesn't match this assumption then it will throw an error. ## Minimum working example ```python import pandas as pd from beakerx import * df = pd.DataFrame({"runway": ["24", "36L"]}) TableDisplay(df) ``` ## Error ``` --------------------------------------------------------------------------- ValueError Traceback (most recent call last) <ipython-input-3-a6495998b2cd> in <module>() ----> 1 TableDisplay(df) /opt/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/beakerx/tabledisplay/tabledisplay.py in __init__(self, *args, **kwargs) 175 def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): 176 super(TableDisplay, self).__init__(**kwargs) --> 177 self.chart = Table(*args, **kwargs) 178 self.model = self.chart.transform() 179 /opt/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/beakerx/tabledisplay/tabledisplay.py in __init__(self, *args, **kwargs) 31 self.hasIndex = None 32 if isinstance(args[0], DataFrame): ---> 33 self.convert_from_pandas(args, types_map) 34 elif isinstance(args[0], dict): 35 self.convert_from_dict(args) /opt/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/beakerx/tabledisplay/tabledisplay.py in convert_from_pandas(self, args, types_map) 104 value_type = types_map.get(columnName) 105 --> 106 row.append(self.convert_value(value, value_type)) 107 if not isinstance(args[0].index, RangeIndex): 108 row[:0] = [self.convert_value(args[0].index.get_values()[index], type(args[0].index.get_values()[index]))] /opt/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/beakerx/tabledisplay/tabledisplay.py in convert_value(value, value_type) 120 def convert_value(value, value_type): 121 if value_type == "time": --> 122 converted_value = DateType(value) 123 elif value_type == "double": 124 converted_value = value.astype('str') /opt/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/beakerx/tabledisplay/tableitems.py in __init__(self, value) 46 47 def __init__(self, value): ---> 48 self.timestamp = parse(value).timestamp() * 1000 49 50 /opt/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/dateutil/parser.py in parse(timestr, parserinfo, **kwargs) 1180 return parser(parserinfo).parse(timestr, **kwargs) 1181 else: -> 1182 return DEFAULTPARSER.parse(timestr, **kwargs) 1183 1184 /opt/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/dateutil/parser.py in parse(self, timestr, default, ignoretz, tzinfos, **kwargs) 557 558 if res is None: --> 559 raise ValueError("Unknown string format") 560 561 if len(res) == 0: ValueError: Unknown string format ```

bug.title: python kernel demos under doc/contents not working in binder
bug.body: Thanks for your work on beakerx. I was curious to see beakerx running, so opted for the short-cut route via the binder button on your README. It could be that these demos are a WIP, but just thought I'd mention that for some reason I was **not** able to get most of the python-based notebooks (e.g. `categoryPlot_python.ipynb`) to output visualisations/charts by performing a `Run All` cells, whereas most of the notebooks with a groovy kernel did work. The only python one that did appear to work was `OutputContainersAndLayoutManagers_python.ipynb`. I was interested to see your `tablesawDemo.ipynb` using quandl data, although that is somehow broken currently. ``` org.codehaus.groovy.control.MultipleCompilationErrorsException: startup failed: script15107884950032073587986.groovy: 2: unable to resolve class Table @ line 2, column 7. Table table = session.getDataSet(DataSetRequest.Builder.of("WIKI/AAPL").build()); ^ script15107884950032073587986.groovy: 4: unable to resolve class ShortColumn @ line 4, column 13. ShortColumn yearColumn = table.dateColumn("Date").year(); ```

bug.title: Make JDBC drivers dynamically loadable
bug.body: http://www.kfu.com/~nsayer/Java/dyn-jdbc.html If you're going to do any sort of database activity in Java, you'll probably be using JDBC. Like ODBC before it, JDBC is a great way to insure that your program is free of any ties to the underlying database. Traditionally, the mechanism is that you put the JDBC driver somewhere in the classpath and then use class.forName() to find and load the driver. One problem with this is that it presumes that your driver is in the classpath. This means either packaging the driver in your jar, or having to stick the driver somewhere (probably unpacking it too), or modifying your classpath. "But why not use something like URLClassLoader and the overload of class.forName() that lets you specify the ClassLoader?" Because the DriverManager will refuse to use a driver not loaded by the system ClassLoader. Ouch! The workaround for this is to create a shim class that implements java.sql.Driver. This shim class will do nothing but call the methods of an instance of a JDBC driver that we loaded dynamically. Something like this: ``` import java.sql.*; class DriverShim implements Driver { private Driver driver; DriverShim(Driver d) { this.driver = d; } public boolean acceptsURL(String u) throws SQLException { return this.driver.acceptsURL(u); } public Connection connect(String u, Properties p) throws SQLException { return this.driver.connect(u, p); } public int getMajorVersion() { return this.driver.getMajorVersion(); } public int getMinorVersion() { return this.driver.getMinorVersion(); } public DriverPropertyInfo[] getPropertyInfo(String u, Properties p) throws SQLException { return this.driver.getPropertyInfo(u, p); } public boolean jdbcCompliant() { return this.driver.jdbcCompliant(); } } class test { public will_not_work() { URL u = new URL("jar:file:/path/to/pgjdbc2.jar!/"); String classname = "org.postgresql.Driver"; URLClassLoader ucl = new URLClassLoader(new URL[] { u }); Class.forName(classname, true, ucl); DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:postgresql://host/db", "user", "pw"); // That will throw SQLException: No suitable driver } public will_work() { URL u = new URL("jar:file:/path/to/pgjdbc2.jar!/"); String classname = "org.postgresql.Driver"; URLClassLoader ucl = new URLClassLoader(new URL[] { u }); Driver d = (Driver)Class.forName(classname, true, ucl).newInstance(); DriverManager.registerDriver(new DriverShim(d)); DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:postgresql://host/db", "user", "pw"); // Success! } ``` will_work() works because DriverShim was loaded by the system class loader, and the DriverManager doesn't care that it invokes a class that wasn't. We must perform the registration on the instance ourselves, because although Class.forName() will cause a registration to take place, that particular registration will fail for the same reason that will_not_work() fails.

bug.title: Problem with console mode and magic commands
bug.body: A bunch of console issues were fixed in #5195. One that slipped by or got introduced more recently involves magic commands. It looks like any magic command will cause the console to error out. Here's an example: ``` (beakerx) Joes-MacBook-Air:~ joe$ jupyter console --kernel=groovy Jupyter console 5.1.0 BeakerX master Groovy 2.4.3 hash 492c381 build time 2017-10-25 10:04 PDT In [1]: 3 + 4 Out[1]: 7 In [2]: %lsmagic Available magic commands: %%javascript %%html %%bash %lsmagic %classpath add jar <jar path> %classpath add mvn <group name version> %classpath remove <jar path> %classpath %import static <classpath> %import <classpath> %unimport <classpath> %time %%time %timeit %%timeit Traceback (most recent call last): File "/Users/joe/miniconda2/envs/beakerx/bin/jupyter-console", line 5, in <module> app.main() File "/Users/joe/miniconda2/envs/beakerx/lib/python3.5/site-packages/jupyter_core/application.py", line 267, in launch_instance return super(JupyterApp, cls).launch_instance(argv=argv, **kwargs) File "/Users/joe/miniconda2/envs/beakerx/lib/python3.5/site-packages/traitlets/config/application.py", line 658, in launch_instance app.start() File "/Users/joe/miniconda2/envs/beakerx/lib/python3.5/site-packages/jupyter_console/app.py", line 155, in start self.shell.mainloop() File "/Users/joe/miniconda2/envs/beakerx/lib/python3.5/site-packages/jupyter_console/ptshell.py", line 490, in mainloop self.interact() File "/Users/joe/miniconda2/envs/beakerx/lib/python3.5/site-packages/jupyter_console/ptshell.py", line 482, in interact self.run_cell(code, store_history=True) File "/Users/joe/miniconda2/envs/beakerx/lib/python3.5/site-packages/jupyter_console/ptshell.py", line 546, in run_cell self.handle_execute_reply(msg_id, timeout=0.05) File "/Users/joe/miniconda2/envs/beakerx/lib/python3.5/site-packages/jupyter_console/ptshell.py", line 564, in handle_execute_reply status = content['status'] KeyError: 'status' (beakerx) Joes-MacBook-Air:~ joe$ ``` The problem doesn't seem to be specific to the magic command (I found it with `%classpath`) or the kernel.

bug.title: Problem with classpath add mvn and transitive dependencies
bug.body: I've been playing with using Spark's ML library in a Scala notebook. The library's linear algebra package depends on Breeze and netlib, and I've been running into things like Caused by: java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: org.netlib.blas.Daxpy from inside the linear algebra package. I narrowed it down to a problem with netlib core: %classpath add mvn com.github.fommil.netlib core 1.1.2 Added jars: [core.jar, arpack_combined_all-javadoc.jar] new org.netlib.blas.Daxpy() <console>:80: error: type Daxpy is not a member of package org.netlib.blas new org.netlib.blas.Daxpy() ^ %classpath add mvn net.sourceforge.f2j arpack_combined_all 0.1 Added jar: [arpack_combined_all.jar] new org.netlib.blas.Daxpy() org.netlib.blas.Daxpy@5ab7837 I managed to find something relevant: sbt/sbt#861 blames it on a bug in Ivy. Notice that the first command loads the javadoc jar instead of the code jar. [This comment](https://github.com/sbt/sbt/issues/861#issuecomment-25919731) says it is "similar to" another Ivy bug that has been fixed, but I didn't get as far as figuring whether there is another Ivy bug filed for precisely this issue. I'm not sure if there's a way to work around this in the implementation, but I want to get the bug filed here because it is likely to affect people trying to use Spark's ML library with the `add mvn` feature, and at least there is a workaround at notebook level by explicitly loading the missing dependency.

bug.title: plotting API should use the index when its input is a `pandas.Series` with an index
bug.body: Currently, the `Line` and `Points` and related classes all take an `x` and `y` parameter. Instead, if the object is a `pandas.Series` which has a meaningful `pandas.Index` assigned (e.g. a `TimestampIndex`), we should use that as the `x` values and the values in the `Series` as the `y` values.

bug.title: plotting API should handle pandas timestamp columns and python datetime columns
bug.body: Input: ```py df.dtypes plot = TimePlot() plot.add(Line(x=df['time'], y=df['openPrice'])) plot.add(Line(x=df['time'], y=df['closePrice'])) ``` Output: ```py time datetime64[ns] openPrice float64 closePrice float64 dtype: object <stacktrace ending in> dateutil/parser.py in __init__(self, instream) 59 if getattr(instream, 'read', None) is None: 60 raise TypeError('Parser must be a string or character stream, not ' ---> 61 '{itype}'.format(itype=instream.__class__.__name__)) 62 63 self.instream = instream TypeError: Parser must be a string or character stream, not Timestamp ``` Currently, for `SimpleTimePlot` (which shows the same error), we need to cast the time column with `df.assign(time=df['time'].astype('str'))`. `TimePlot` also displays results when you cast it this way (they come out as `YYYY-MM-DD` strings), but interprets them as time points in 1970 when they're actually dates in 2017. We should make sure both APIs behave the same, can parse date strings correctly, and also can handle `pd.Timestamp`s, `datetime.datetime`s, `datetime.date`s, and `numpy` `datetime64` types.

bug.title: EasyForm text field width

bug.title: easyform list component too wide
bug.body: groovy code like this should make the component only as wide as it needs to be, instead of a constant width. ``` def f = new EasyForm("Form name") f.addList("pick", ["a", "b", "c", "dasdf"], true) f ``` this one is more correct, the width looks right but there is a bogus scrollbar ``` def f = new EasyForm("Form name") f.addList("pick", ["a", "b", "c", "dasdf"], false) f ```

bug.title: python easyform radiobuttons first selected by default
bug.body: ``` f = EasyForm("myform") f.addRadioButtons("pickme", ["a", "b", "c"]) f ``` run this python cell. in the result "a" is selected. run the equivalent groovy code. no button is selected. python should be like groovy. if you access the value, and no button is selected yet, then the result should be "None".

bug.title: python SimpleTimePlot problem
bug.body: put this data into a file "data.csv": ``` timestamp,temp 2017-09-26 09:03:09.420312465,49.12 2017-09-26 09:03:50.401026408,49.14 2017-09-26 09:03:50.401446408,49.14 2017-09-26 09:03:50.401448428,49.14 2017-09-26 09:03:50.403219439,49.13 2017-09-26 09:03:50.403220752,49.12 2017-09-26 09:03:50.420850884,49.12 ``` then run this cell: ``` b2 = pd.read_csv("data.csv") b2.index = b2['timestamp'] SimpleTimePlot(b2, ['temp']) ``` and get this error: ``` site-packages/beakerx/plot/chart.py in __init__(self, *args, **kwargs) 382 383 for row in tableData: --> 384 x = row[timeColumn] 385 x = date_time_2_millis(x) 386 xs.append(x) KeyError: 'time' ``` seems we look for "time" as a constant. if the dataframe has an index then we should use that column for time. if no index is specified, then try to find "time".

bug.title: Plots with some unicode symbols in title are not displayed.
bug.body: Very bizarre error. Some of plots in my old beaker notebook are not displayed (no error, in fact no output cell at all). I found that the ones that are not displayed are those that have some specific Cyrillic letters in the title. If I avoid specific letters like `` or ``, everything works fine. To reproduce try: ``` new Plot(title: "") ``` The system locale is Windows-1252. **EDIT** There is in fact a error stack trace in the console: ``` Traceback (most recent call last): File "c:\anaconda\lib\site-packages\tornado\web.py", line 1467, in _stack_context_handle_exception raise_exc_info((type, value, traceback)) File "<string>", line 4, in raise_exc_info File "c:\anaconda\lib\site-packages\tornado\stack_context.py", line 316, in wrapped ret = fn(*args, **kwargs) File "c:\anaconda\lib\site-packages\zmq\eventloop\zmqstream.py", line 191, in <lambda> self.on_recv(lambda msg: callback(self, msg), copy=copy) File "c:\anaconda\lib\site-packages\notebook\services\kernels\handlers.py", line 299, in _on_zmq_reply msg = self.session.deserialize(fed_msg_list) File "c:\anaconda\lib\site-packages\jupyter_client\session.py", line 926, in deserialize message['content'] = self.unpack(msg_list[4]) File "c:\anaconda\lib\site-packages\jupyter_client\session.py", line 105, in <lambda> json_unpacker = lambda s: jsonapi.loads(s) File "c:\anaconda\lib\site-packages\zmq\utils\jsonapi.py", line 54, in loads s = s.decode('utf8') UnicodeDecodeError: 'utf-8' codec can't decode byte 0xd1 in position 172: invalid continuation byte ```

bug.title: Plot export error - Entity 'nbsp' not defined
bug.body: Example: ``` Random random = new Random(); data1 = []; data2 = []; (1..10000).each { data1 << random.nextGaussian(); data2 << 2*random.nextGaussian() + 1.0; } new Histogram(data: data1, binCount: 25); ``` When I export this plot as svg, the svg file contains an error - Entity 'nbsp' not defined. I can save .svg file but it is not correct. There is screenshot of the svg file opened in browsers: Chrome: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6450797/30171856-5bc68326-93f3-11e7-87f8-de996ccce9a2.png) Firefox: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6450797/30171905-7d27c4e4-93f3-11e7-9d71-1d6af8b9e51c.png) When this error occurs exporting as png doesn't work. This bug affects only a few examples. For example this presented below works well: ``` Random random = new Random(); data1 = []; data2 = []; (1..10000).each { data1 << random.nextGaussian(); data2 << 2*random.nextGaussian() + 1.0; } new Histogram(initWidth:800, initHeight:200, title:"Wide Histogram with Manual Parameters", xLabel:"Size", yLabel:"Count", rangeMin: -8, rangeMax: 8, data: data1 + [7]*200, binCount: 99, color: new Color(0, 154, 166)); ```

bug.title: %defaultDatasource crashes SQL kernel
bug.body: If you give no parameters the kernel crashes as follows: ``` Exception in thread "Thread-0" java.lang.RuntimeException: Wrong format. at com.twosigma.beakerx.kernel.commands.MagicCommand.lambda$dataSource$22(MagicCommand.java:116) at com.twosigma.beakerx.kernel.commands.MagicCommand.lambda$process$21(MagicCommand.java:97) at java.util.ArrayList.forEach(ArrayList.java:1249) at com.twosigma.beakerx.kernel.commands.MagicCommand.process(MagicCommand.java:95) ```

bug.title: grape not working
bug.body: from @altavir https://github.com/twosigma/beakerx/issues/5836#issuecomment-322266351: I just tried to use `Grape` itself in groovy kernel and it does not work which is strange. This code: ```groovy // https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/commons-io/commons-io @Grapes( @Grab(group='commons-io', module='commons-io', version='2.5') ) import org.apache.commons.io.Charsets println Charsets.US_ASCII ``` produces an error: ``` java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/apache/ivy/core/report/ResolveReport at com.twosigma.beakerx.groovy.evaluator.GroovyEvaluator$workerThread$MyRunnable.run(GroovyEvaluator.java:461) ``` It worked in the old beaker. Fix suggested by @jpallas: I don't know much about the old beaker, so I couldn't say why Grape worked in it. The BeakerX Groovy kernel is built using the `groovy-all` artifact, which has Ivy marked as an optional dependency, and the current kernel build does not explicitly add an Ivy dependency. So the failure above would be expected.

bug.title: Adding class path with wildcard calls resetEnvironment repeatedly, can be very slow
bug.body: If I use the `%classpath add jar /path/to/dir/*` wildcard mechanism, the default behavior (in `BaseEvaluator.addJarToClassPath`, called indirectly by `MagicCommand.classpathAddJar`) will end up calling `resetEnvironment` once for each jar file. Now, the Scala interpreter is famously slow to start up, which even the most ardent fans will admit. The consequence in my case was that adding 209 jar files (from the Spark `jars` directory) blocked my Scala notebook for over ten minutes. I didn't do actual profiling, but every time I ran jstack I saw `resetEnvironment` in the stack, so I'm fairly confident about the cause.

bug.title: "hide all columns" with many columns hangs
bug.body: run this cell from the "big tables" demo: ``` ArrayList rowList = new ArrayList(); for(int row = 0 ; row< 10 ; row++){ HashMap colMap = new HashMap(); for(int col = 0 ; col< 1006; col++){ colMap.put('a' + col, 'b' + col); } rowList.add(colMap); } def display = new TableDisplay(rowList); display ``` you will get a prompt about too many columns. click "ok" the menu opens. skip the menu with all the checkboxes and instead select "hide all columns". the tab freezes for a while, and though it comes back eventually, the page is useless and will hang again. maybe a memory leak? maybe it should only redraw the table after the loop completes?

bug.title: Current Scala version (2.12) is not compatible with current Spark
bug.body: The current stable Spark release (2.1) is based on Scala 2.11 and incompatible with Scala 2.12, and the upcoming 2.2 release is also not supporting Scala 2.12 (see [mail thread](http://apache-spark-developers-list.1001551.n3.nabble.com/RFC-removing-Scala-2-10-tp21116p21124.html)). Of course, Scala 2.12 has other benefits, including better integration and performance with Java 8. And unless/until the Spark/Scala integration of classic Beaker can be ported to the BeakerX Scala kernel, maybe it's not that important.

``` new MIMEContainer('text/html', '

Hello World!

') ``` you used to be able to create a result with an arbitrary mime type like this but it doesn't work now.

bug.title: confusion about magic commands implementation
bug.body: I've been trying to understand the magic commands implementation since discovering that my fix for reporting incomplete input in Scala causes complaints when line magics are used. As best I can tell, what happens is that the Scala interpreter is being passed an empty string (which it considers incomplete input) because `MagicCommandResult.hasCodeToExecute()` is returning true, while `MagicCommandResult.getCode().asString()` is an empty string. I'm pretty sure that `hasCodeToExecute` should not be true if there's no non-magic code, but the parsing in `Code` is a little hard to follow and the semantics for `MagicCommandResult` are not clear. When I try to "fix" things, I wind up calling `sendMagicCommandResult` while the `resultMessage` and `replyWithoutStatus` of the `MagicCommandResult` are null. These are actually `Optional` in `MagicCommandResultItem`, but `MagicCommandResult` unconditionally calls `get()` on them. I'm not sure I understand the design well enough to fix the problem without breaking something else. Help?

bug.title: font is set too late
bug.body: the notebook loads and then the fonts flash. can it be immediately set?

bug.title: change table interaction action names to be compatible with classic beaker
bug.body: in classic beaker, a cell run by the table API would look like: ``` def details = display.details switch(details.actionType){ case 'DOUBLE_CLICK': print ("You clicked on the cell [" + details.row + ", " + details.col + "]") break; case 'CONTEXT_MENU_CLICK': print ("You selected context menu '" + details.contextMenuItem + "' on the cell [" + details.row + ", " + details.col + "]") break; } ``` in BeakerX this is now: ``` def details = display.details switch(details.actionType){ case 'ONDOUBLECLICK': print ("You clicked on the cell [" + details.row + ", " + details.col + "]") break; case 'ONCONTEXTMENU': print ("You selected context menu '" + details.contextMenuItem + "' on the cell [" + details.row + ", " + details.col + "]") break; } ``` please change to use the original Beaker names "DOUBLE_CLICK" and "CONTEXT_MENU_CLICK"

bug.title: problems with handling of magic commands
bug.body: There seem to be a couple of problems with magic commands. Currently, output from the first magic command appears in the notebook, but the cell is never marked as completed and subsequent executions are blocked. In `ExecuteRequestHandler.handleMsg`, the non-magic case passes a callback lambda to `executeCode` that sends an idle message and releases the sync object. Since the magic command path doesn't use queue-with-callback model, it seems like these two operations are needed inline. Also, in `MessageCreator.createMagicMessage`, the reply-without-status message is being "published" (to the I/O socket) instead of being "sent" (to the shell socket). I have these changes ready for a PR. In the broader picture, there something inconsistent about `createMagicMessage` and the control flow. Its peer `createMessage` returns a list of `MessageHolder`s, while `createMagicMessage` actually dispatches the messages instead of returning them. Maybe that was because of the callback/no-callback difference, but it's not ideal for code comprehension. On the other hand, the processing of a list of `MessageHolder`s is inside `ExecutionResultSender` and not exposed, so there would need to be either some duplication of functionality or non-trivial refactoring to clean that up.

bug.title: Java imports need to be further adjusted for Scala
bug.body: Since the Scala kernel is using the default JVM imports, two adjustments are needed beyond the already implemented changing of the wildcard. They are: 1. Remove `static` 2. Escape the package name `object`, which is a Scala keyword. (This is used in one of the default import paths, `com.twosigma.beaker.jvm.object.OutputCell`.) On the second point, it's conceivable that other Scala keywords that aren't Java keywords might show up in package names, but no others seem very likely, so a one-off replacement is probably fine.

bug.title: Remove tablesaw dependency from core (make optional)
bug.body: Tablesaw is a beast. It looks harmless (seemingly no dependencies), but that is because it is a **fat jar**, that includes _copies_ of many many large dependencies. This will eventually cause major version problems, when the user wants to use a newer version of any of these dependencies, and you end up having multiple versions on the classpath. https://github.com/lwhite1/tablesaw/blob/master/pom.xml Some (first order only) of the dependencies "secretly" coming with tablesaw: - antlr 4.0.7 <-- beaker uses 4.5 - guava 19.0 <-- beaker uses 18 - gson 2.5 - JavaFastPFOR - jackson-dataformat-csv 2.7.5 - commons-collections4 4.0 - commons-math3 3.6.1 - commons-lang3 3.3.2 - opencsv 3.8 - snappy 0.4 - RoaringBitmap 0.6.5 - fastutil 7.0.10 - smile-plot 1.2.2 - xchart 3.2.0 - smile-core 1.2.2 - h2 1.4.193 It would be better to use a **lean** dependency instead.

bug.title: interrupt should not query kernel
bug.body: https://github.com/twosigma/beakerx/blob/master/beakerx/js/src/extension.js#L103 this code has 2 problems: ``` function interrupt() { getControllCommandList(function(resp) { if (undefined != resp.content.data) { ``` the first thing this does is query the kernel for its capabilities. this is wrong. this was already done when the kernel started up. the result should be stored locally in this module, and then used here when its needed. also "getControllCommandList" has a typo, it should be "getControlCommandList"

graxxia-0.9.jar groovy-2.3.4.jar groovy-all-2.4.3.jar groovy-pathing.jar groovy.jar groovycsv-1.0.jar guava-18.0.jar guice-3.0.jar guice-servlet-3.0.jar httpclient-4.5.1.jar httpcore-4.4.3.jar itext-2.1.7.jar ivy-2.2.0.jar jackson-core-asl-1.9.13.jar jackson-jaxrs-1.9.13.jar jackson-mapper-asl-1.9.13.jar javax.inject-1.jar javax.servlet-3.0.0.v201112011016.jar javax.ws.rs-api-2.0-m10.jar jaxb-impl-2.1.13.jar jersey-core-1.17.1.jar jersey-guice-1.17.1.jar jersey-server-1.17.1.jar jersey-servlet-1.17.1.jar jetty-client-7.6.13.v20130916.jar jetty-continuation-8.1.13.v20130916.jar jetty-http-8.1.13.v20130916.jar jetty-io-8.1.13.v20130916.jar jetty-jmx-7.6.13.v20130916.jar jetty-security-8.1.13.v20130916.jar jetty-server-8.1.13.v20130916.jar jetty-servlet-8.1.13.v20130916.jar jetty-util-8.1.13.v20130916.jar jetty-websocket-7.6.13.v20130916.jar jsr250-api-1.0.jar junit-4.4.jar jvm.jar log4j-1.2.17.jar opencsv-2.1.jar org.abego.treelayout.core-1.0.1.jar shared.jar slf4j-api-1.7.6.jar slf4j-simple-1.7.6.jar stax2-api-3.1.1.jar woodstox-core-asl-4.2.0.jar wsdl4j-1.6.3.jar xmlschema-core-2.0.3.jar ``` There are two different versions of groovy as well as copies of the same library with different name (the library itself is quite outdated). There is `Junit` there, which makes no sense. Half of the libraries are duplicated in other jvm plugins and in core.

bug.title: clicking on filename opens save dialog twice
bug.body: to reproduce: * click on the filename, to the right of the logo * type a name, click OK result: the file dialog opens again expected: the file is saved and the dialog vanishes

bug.title: build and test electron on linux
bug.body: i think save and save-as are broken

bug.body: https://github.com/twosigma/beaker-notebook/pull/4887/files

bug.title: time column shows up as [object Object]
bug.body: to reproduce: - open file:config/tutorials/ipython-examples.bkr - scroll down to the table, select "download as CSV" from the table menu - look at the contents of the csv file result: Index column every row is `[object Object]` expected: 1st column are the dates & times as seen in the notebook

bug.title: run button stays highlighted
bug.body: when you hover over the big run button it turns dark. if you click it, and run the cell, then it stays dark, even after the mouse moves away. it should return to it's normal color when the execution completes.

bug.title: category plot fails to promote list to 1xN array
bug.body: ``` new CategoryPlot(categoryNames: ["a", "b"]) << new CategoryBars(value: [1.1, 2.2]) ``` produces ``` java.lang.ArrayStoreException at com.twosigma.beaker.chart.categoryplot.plotitem.CategoryGraphics.setValue(CategoryGraphics.java:215) ``` instead of a plot. It should promote [1.1, 2.2] to [[1.1, 2.2]] and produce a plot like this:https://pub.beakernotebook.com/publications/0757ef56-9aec-11e6-a6e1-170753a079d9

bug.title: save-as opens save dialog twice
bug.body: open a new notebook, use the save-as menu item, type a filename, hit return. result: dialog opens again. expected behavior: we return to editing.

bug.title: restart needed to update default notebook
bug.body: to reproduce: - run beaker - from the start page click on "new default notebook" - copy a notebook to ~/.beaker/v1/config/default-notebook.bkr - from the start page click on "new default notebook" result: you get a 2nd copy of the default. expected: the notebook you copied in should appear instead the server should read the file every time the rest/util/getDefaultNotebook should deliver new version. it should not be cached. maybe just change to post?

bug.title: ipython broken in docker container
easyform date picker should accept java date, not just string
bug.body: https://pub.beakernotebook.com/publications/5584d6fc-9a11-11e6-9a2f-2bd3713b5b03

bug.title: replacing text breaks evaluation
bug.body: to reproduce: - new empty notebook - add JS cell, enter `"abc"`, run the cell. note output is abc. - open find-and-replace, type abc TAB xyz, click "replace all" - click "run" on the cell result: output is abc again expected: output is xyz

bug.title: pub broken
bug.body: when i go to file -> publish menu, log in, and click "publish" it opens a new window and redirects to `https://pub.beakernotebook.com/publications/featured#%2Fpublications%2Fe4f95c6a-9861-11e6-9fbd-e32d9c88b3a8` but it should be `https://pub.beakernotebook.com/publications/e4f95c6a-9861-11e6-9fbd-e32d9c88b3a8` the server changed the format for the URLs, the client needs to follow suit.

bug.title: crash during startup if missing backend

bug.title: search in vim mode should start from current cursor
bug.body: # create a code cell with the following contents: ``` abc abc ``` enter vim mode, and put the cursor in the middle empty line, and hit `/` to start a search. type "abc" return. result: the cursor ends up on the 1st abc expected result: it should be the 2nd abc.

bug.title: save csv should encode html
bug.body: evaluate the following groovy: ``` [row1: "This & that", row2: "This / that", row3: "This > that"] ``` then in the resulting table, use the "Download all as CSV" menu item, and look at the result. the non-alphabetic characters appear as HTML entitites eg `>` but should be regular ascii >

bug.title: find and replace with hidden code
bug.body: if a code cell has its input collapsed, and you are doing a search and replace, and there is a match in the hidden code then the cell should open when it gets the orange highlighted (when you "next" into it), and close again if as you continue to "next" you leave that cell. also, if the matching text is visible in the one line summary of the collapsed cell, then it should get the yellow highlight. this is tricky to implement because we do not want to change the notebook model at actually open that cell. instead, the angular predicate that shows the cells should have another condition for when there is a match in progress.

bug.title: column menu format problem
bug.body: same as https://github.com/twosigma/beaker-notebook/issues/4778 but for the format menu (change the number of digits) shown.

bug.title: stack trace on close
bug.body: 1) create a new empty notebook. 2) add a JS cell. 3) File -> Close the following appears on console: ``` beakerVendor.js:63042 ReferenceError: onGutterClick is not defined at beakerApp.js:11888 at Scope.$broadcast (beakerVendor.js:67044) at Scope.$destroy (beakerVendor.js:66662) at ngRepeatAction (beakerVendor.js:78467) at $watchCollectionAction (beakerVendor.js:66430) at Scope.$digest (beakerVendor.js:66565) at Scope.$apply (beakerVendor.js:66829) at done (beakerVendor.js:61064) at completeRequest (beakerVendor.js:61270) at XMLHttpRequest.requestLoaded (beakerVendor.js:61203) ``` the function is fine but it should not produce errors.

bug.title: race condition in autocomplete
bug.body: during autocomplete, if you press down arrow and then before the new function's parameters and documentation are fetched and displayed, if you hit return then you get mangled code inserted into the code cell and the documentation window gets stuck open and can't be closed. this can be difficult to reproduce, probably to really debug it you should hack the server to slow down the autocomplete service.

bug.title: column formatting change should keep column visible
bug.body: 1. make the browser window narrow (10cm) 2. run this python3 code to get a table. ``` import pandas as pd pd.DataFrame(np.random.randn(10,25)) ``` 1. use the table H scrollbar to go out to column 12 2. click the column menu and select "align center" result: the table scrolls back to the 1st column. expected: the H position should not change.

bug.title: table column menus mispositioned
bug.body: 1. make the browser window narrow (10cm) 2. run this python3 code to get a table. ``` import pandas as pd pd.DataFrame(np.random.randn(10,25)) ``` 1. use the table H scrollbar to go out to column 12 2. click the column menu and select "align center" 3. scroll horizontally back to column 12, it should be centered. 4. click the column menu again, it does not seem to appear! 5. scroll the notebook (not the table) to the right, the menu is floating out there.

bug.title: Save as shortcut command works as Save command
bug.body: Save as shortcut doesn't work, it just saves the notebook.

bug.title: R warning suppresses error
bug.body: as a result of https://github.com/twosigma/beaker-notebook/issues/4295 if there is a warning from R code, and an error, then only the warning is shown. afaik this is always better but maybe there is some cmd where there is a bad warning but a good error. basically after 4295, `read.csv("XXX")` produces ``` "cannot open file 'XXX': No such file or directory" ``` but not ``` Error in file(file, "rt") : cannot open the connection ```

bug.title: clicking on line-numbers broken
bug.body: if you click on a line-number of a code cell it should select that line (and dragging). this is broken. this is a recent regression.

bug.title: shift-click below code cell
bug.body: should select from the current cursor to the end of the code, but it just moves the cursor to the end (ignoring shift). the exact place to click is to the right of the "Run" button. this area is outside the code mirror, but inside the code cell.

bug.title: remove gradient from find and replace window border
bug.body: both default and ambience themes have this problem but it's easier to see in ambiance: ![screen shot 2016-09-22 at 10 49 39 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/963093/18753101/5fc8e108-80b2-11e6-9684-f03df04d8ae0.png) border should be constant solid, like the top. the line on the left side changes color.

bug.title: List of objects not displaying as table
bug.body: 1. Put this code in a Groovy cell: data = new groovy.json.JsonSlurper().parseText(new URL("http://data.consumerfinance.gov/api/views.json").text) 2. Run it 3. You will see the string representation. Click the output cell menu, then Display -> Table and the output cell will be blank.

bug.title: undo ipywidgets code generation
bug.body: https://github.com/twosigma/beaker-notebook/pull/4037 go back to previous simpler method of handling ipywidgets by reverting this PR. how much of this was already done for https://github.com/twosigma/beaker-notebook/issues/4570 ?

bug.title: add hysteresis to submenu closing
bug.body: if you move the mouse to a menu item with a submenu, the submenu opens. if you then move the mouse in a straight line to one of the submenu items (as pictures below), the mouse briefly leaves the current item before entering the submenu (in the picture, it traverses the "upload (.bkr)" item). at this point the menu closes. this is a bug. the submenu should stay open for about 0.3s if the mouse is over another item instead of closing instantly, UNLESS that other item also has a submenu, then the delay should be short-circuited. this should apply to all submenus. ![screen shot 2016-09-20 at 3 29 07 pm 2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/963093/18685824/ac34bc40-7f47-11e6-971a-6c39c6c384d7.png)

bug.title: sluggish menus and everything

bug.title: pasting image while editing text goes to wrong place
bug.body: if no cell is active, if you paste an image then a new cell is created with the image. that's good. but if you already have a text cell open and the cursor is active, and you paste, the image should go into the current cell. instead it still creates a new cell.

bug.title: improve scroll to reveal search hit
bug.body: in the find/replace dialog, when you click "find", if necessary it scrolls to show the found text. however it does not account for the fact that the find/replace dialog itself hides the bottom of the notebook. fix this so found text is always visible. to reproduce: 1) open the main tutorial, 2) open the find/replace dialog, 3) adjust the window height so you see this: 4) type "note" in the find box and click "find next". result: nothing visible happens expected result: highlighted text scroll into view. in fact the text has been highlighted, but you have to manually scroll to see it: note that this in combination with https://github.com/twosigma/beaker-notebook/issues/4727 is more complex because you must also account for the horizontal position, because that can now change the visibility.

During this operation the status should say "Killing all threads..."

bug.title: submenus should not close when mouse leaves

bug.title: JavaScript cells issues
bug.body: Publication with errors listed below: https://pub.beakernotebook.com/publications/6d2bf138-5d3e-11e6-8856-6f89c25d636c # When code cell returns promise, resolved value is checked only for circularity (no `isBeakerObject` check is present). That means that beakerObject returned from promise emits error on cell 'no circular object allowed'. ``` beaker.newPromise().then(function() { return beaker; }); ``` Calling `beaker.print` after `beaker.evaluate` cell gets error but without any message. It may be happening because calling `beaker.evaluate` changes `_beaker_model_output` to other cell output and it isn't restored after that cell finishes evaluating. (replace cell-id below with some existing cell id in notebook) ``` beaker.evaluate('codelkGNKr').then(function() { beaker.print('something after evaluation'); }); ``` Calling `beaker.print` from `beaker.evaluateCode` doesn't work (not sure if bug, or just incorrect usage) ``` beaker.evaluateCode('JavaScript', 'beaker.print("something")') ```

bug.title: Null handling in JavaScript cell output
bug.body: Right now JavaScript cells don't have any way to handle payload / output with `null` value. fun fact: `(typeof null === 'object') === true` Also when output from cell is promise that resolves to undefined it get mapped by `beakerObj.transform()` from `payload: undefined` to `payload: null` and this makes further errors as result / payload is checked only for being `undefined` and not for being `null`.

bug.title: server crash from closing a notebook from the start page while it is still open
bug.body: if you open a notebook, and then open the start page in another tab, and then click the "close" button, then go back to the tab where the notebook is still open, and then edit or save it, the server crashes: ``` java.lang.NullPointerException at com.twosigma.beaker.core.rest.SessionBackupRest.setEdited(SessionBackupRest.java:223) ``` instead you should get a pop-up notification "this session has been closed from another window" similar to https://github.com/twosigma/beaker-notebook/pull/4308

bug.title: editing text cell should mark notebook as edited sooner
bug.body: if you edit a text cell, the notebook is not marked as edited until the cell is formatted (eg by clicking elsewhere in the UI). however, the document model has been updated, eg if you press save you get what you typed. so it should be marked as dirty right away.

bug.title: show/hide should mark notebook as edited
bug.body: both code cell inputs and outputs, the show/hide toggle is part of the document so if you change it, the notebook should be marked as edited (\* appears next to filename and server notified). also a bug for text cells, and sections.

bug.title: progress timer causes reflow
bug.body: run the 1st cell of progressUpdate.bkr and notice that the red cancel button and the elements to its right shift left and right as the timer runs. open the network tab in chrome and observe many red bars, it is reflowing 10 times per second. easy fix would seem to be putting the time into a div with a fixed width.
